ol.li: Understand the relationship between matrix products and compositions of matrix transformations.
Become comfortable doing basic algebra involving matrices.

introduction.p: In this section, we study compositions of transformations. As we will see, composition is a way of chaining transformations together. The composition of matrix transformations corresponds to a notion of multiplying two matrices together. We also discuss addition and scalar multiplication of transformations and of matrices.

subsection.title: Composition of linear transformations
subsection.p: Composition means the same thing in linear algebra as it does in Calculus. Here is the definition.

statement.p: Let T\colon\R^n\to\R^m and U\colon\R^p\to\R^n be transformations. Their composition is the transformation T\circ U\colon\R^p\to\R^m defined by (T\circ U)(x) = T(U(x)).

bluebox.title: Domain and codomain of a composition

ul.li: In order for T\circ U to be defined, the codomain of U must equal the domain of T.
The domain of T\circ U is the domain of U.
The codomain of T\circ U is the codomain of T.

example.title: Functions of one variable
example.p: Define f\colon\R\to\R by f(x) = x^2 and g\colon\R\to\R by g(x) = x^3. The composition f\circ g\colon\R\to\R is the transformation defined by the rule f\circ g(x) = f(g(x)) = f(x^3) = (x^3)^2 = x^6. For instance, f\circ g(-2) = f(-8) = 64.

example.title: Interactive: A composition of matrix transformations
example.p: Define T\colon\R^3\to\R^2 and U\colon\R^2\to\R^3 by T(x) = \mat{1 1 0; 0 1 1}x \sptxt{and} U(x) = \mat{1 0; 0 1; 1 0}x. Their composition is a transformation T\circ U\colon\R^2\to\R^2; it turns out to be the matrix transformation associated to the matrix \bigl(\begin{smallmatrix}1\amp1\\1\amp1\end{smallmatrix}\bigr).

The vector x is the input of U and of T\circ U; the vector in the middle is the output of U/the input of T, and the vector on the right is the output of T/of T\circ U. Click and drag x.

subsection.p: Recall from this that the identity transformation is the transformation \operatorname{Id}_{\R^n}\colon\R^n\to\R^n defined by \operatorname{Id}_{\R^n}(x) = x for every vector x.

note.title: Properties of composition
note.p:
Let S,T,U be transformations and let c be a scalar. Suppose that T\colon\R^n\to\R^m, and that in each of the following identities, the domains and the codomains are compatible when necessary for the composition to be defined. The following properties are easily verified:
S\circ(T+U) \amp= S\circ T+S\circ U \amp (S + T)\circ U \amp= S\circ U + T\circ U \amp
c(T\circ U) \amp= (cT)\circ U \amp c(T\circ U) \amp= T\circ(cU) \rlap{\;\;\text{ if $T$ is linear}}
T\circ\operatorname{Id}_{\R^n} \amp= T \amp \operatorname{Id}_{\R^m}\circ T \amp= T
\amp \amp S\circ(T\circ U) \amp= (S\circ T)\circ U \amp

subsection.p: The final property is called associativity. Unwrapping both sides, it says: S\circ(T\circ U)(x) = S(T\circ U(x)) = S(T(U(x))) = S\circ T(U(x)) = (S\circ T)\circ U(x). In other words, both S\circ (T\circ U) and (S\circ T)\circ U are the transformation defined by first applying U, then T, then S.

bluebox.p: Composition of transformations is not commutative in general. That is, in general, T\circ U\neq U\circ T, even when both compositions are defined.

example.title: Functions of one variable
example.p: Define f\colon\R\to\R by f(x) = x^2 and g\colon\R\to\R by g(x) = e^x. The composition f\circ g\colon\R\to\R is the transformation defined by the rule f\circ g(x) = f(g(x)) = f(e^x) = (e^x)^2 = e^{2x}. The composition g\circ f\colon\R\to\R is the transformation defined by the rule g\circ f(x) = g(f(x)) = g(x^2) = e^{x^2}. Note that e^{x^2}\neq e^{2x} in general; for instance, if x=1 then e^{x^2} = e and e^{2x} = e^2. Thus f \circ g is not equal to g \circ f, and we can already see with functions of one variable that composition of functions is not commutative.

example.title: Non-commutative composition of transformations
example.p: Define matrix transformations T,U\colon\R^2\to\R^2 by T(x) = \mat{1 1; 0 1}x \sptxt{and} U(x) = \mat{1 0; 1 1}x. Geometrically, T is a shear in the x-direction, and U is a shear in the Y-direction. We evaluate T\circ U\vec{1 0} = T\vec{1 1} = \vec{2 1} and U\circ T\vec{1 0} = U\vec{1 0} = \vec{1 1}. Since T\circ U and U\circ T have different outputs for the input vector 1\choose 0, they are different transformations. (See this .)

subsection.title: Matrix multiplication
subsection.p: In this subsection, we introduce a seemingly unrelated operation on matrices, namely, matrix multiplication. As we will see in the next subsection, matrix multiplication exactly corresponds to the composition of the corresponding linear transformations. First we need some terminology.

notation.description: The i,j entry of a matrix

statement.p: Let A be an m\times n matrix and let B be an n\times p matrix. Denote the columns of B by v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p: B = \mat{| | ,, |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_p; | | ,, |}. The product AB is the m\times p matrix with columns Av_1,Av_2,\ldots,Av_p: AB = \mat{| | ,, |; Av_1 Av_2 \cdots, Av_p; | | ,, |}.

subsection.p: In other words, matrix multiplication is defined column-by-column, or distributes over the columns of B.
In order for the vectors Av_1,Av_2,\ldots,Av_p to be defined, the numbers of rows of B has to equal the number of columns of A.

bluebox.title: The sizes of the matrices in the matrix product

ul.li: In order for AB to be defined, the number of rows of B has to equal the number of columns of A.

\def\r{\textcolor{red}}\def\b{\textcolor{blue}}
The product of an \b m\times\r n matrix and an \r n\times\b p matrix is an \b m\times\b p matrix.

subsection.p: Matrix multiplicationand the matrix-vector product Matrix-vector productand matrix multiplication If B has only one column, then AB also has one column. A matrix with one column is the same as a vector, so the definition of the matrix product generalizes the definition of the matrix-vector product from this .
Matrix multiplicationpowers Power of a matrixMatrix multiplication If A is a square matrix, then we can multiply it by itself; we define its powers to be A^2 = AA \qquad A^3 = AAA \qquad \text{etc.}

paragraphs.title: The row-column rule for matrix multiplication
paragraphs.p: Recall from this that the product of a row vector and a column vector is the scalar \mat{a_1 a_2 \cdots, a_n} \vec{x_1 x_2 \vdots, x_n} = a_1x_1 + a_2x_2 + \cdots + a_nx_n. The following procedure for finding the matrix product is much better adapted to computations by hand; the previous is more suitable for proving theorems, such as this below.

bluebox.title: Recipe: The row-column rule for matrix multiplication

subsection.p: Although matrix multiplication satisfies many of the properties one would expect (see the end of the section), one must be careful when doing matrix arithmetic, as there are several properties that are not satisfied in general.

ul.li: Matrix multiplication is not commutative: AB is not usually equal to BA, even when both products are defined and have the same size. See this .
It is possible for AB=0, even when A\neq 0 and B\neq 0. For example, \mat{1 0; 1 0}\mat{0 0; 1 1} = \mat{0 0; 0 0}.

subsection.p: While matrix multiplication is not commutative in general there are examples of matrices A and B with AB=BA. For example, this always works when A is the zero matrix, or when A=B. The reader is encouraged to find other examples.

example.title: Non-commutative multiplication of matrices
example.p: Consider the matrices A = \mat{1 1; 0 1} \sptxt{and} B = \mat{1 0; 1 1}, as in this . The matrix AB is \mat{1 1; 0 1}\mat{1 0; 1 1} = \mat{2 1; 1 1}, whereas the matrix BA is \mat{1 0; 1 1}\mat{1 1; 0 1} = \mat{1 1; 1 2}. In particular, we have AB \neq BA. And so matrix multiplication is not always commutative. It is not a coincidence that this example agrees with the previous ; we are about to see that multiplication of matrices corresponds to composition of transformations.

example.title: Order of Operations
example.p: Let T\colon\R^n\to\R^m and U\colon\R^p\to\R^n be linear transformations, and let A and B be their standard matrices, respectively. Recall that T\circ U(x) is the vector obtained by first applying U to x, and then T.

On the matrix side, the standard matrix of T\circ U is the product AB, so T\circ U(x) = (AB)x. By associativity of matrix multiplication, we have (AB)x = A(Bx), so the product (AB)x can be computed by first multiplying x by B, then multipyling the product by A.

Therefore, matrix multiplication happens in the same order as composition of transformations. In other words, both matrices and transformations are written in the order opposite from the order in which they act. But matrix multiplication and composition of transformations are written in the same order as each other: the matrix for T\circ U is AB.

subsection.title: Composition and Matrix Multiplication
subsection.p: The point of this subsection is to show that matrix multiplication corresponds to composition of transformations, that is, the standard matrix for T \circ U is the product of the standard matrices for T and for U. It should be hard to believe that our complicated formula for matrix multiplication actually means something intuitive such as chaining two transformations together!

statement.p: Let T\colon\R^n\to\R^m and U\colon\R^p\to\R^n be linear transformations, and let A and B be their standard matrices, respectively, so A is an m\times n matrix and B is an n\times p matrix. Then T\circ U\colon\R^p\to\R^m is a linear transformation, and its standard matrix is the product AB.

proof.p: Now that we know that T\circ U is linear, it makes sense to compute its standard matrix. Let C be the standard matrix of T\circ U, so T(x) = Ax, U(x) = Bx, and T\circ U(x) = Cx. By this , the first column of C is Ce_1, and the first column of B is Be_1. We have T\circ U(e_1) = T(U(e_1)) = T(Be_1) = A(Be_1). By definition, the first column of the product AB is the product of A with the first column of B, which is Be_1, so Ce_1 = T\circ U(e_1) = A(Be_1) = (AB)e_1. It follows that C has the same first column as AB. The same argument as applied to the ith standard coordinate vector e_i shows that C and AB have the same ith column; since they have the same columns, they are the same matrix.

subsection.p: The theorem justifies our choice of definition of the matrix product. This is the one and only reason that matrix products are defined in this way. To rephrase:

bluebox.title: Products and compositions
bluebox.p: The matrix of the composition of two linear transformations is the product of the matrices of the transformations.

Their composition is a linear transformation T\circ U\colon\R^2\to\R^2. By the , its standard matrix is \mat{1 1 0; 0 1 1}\mat{1 0; 0 1; 1 0} = \mat{1 1; 1 1}, as we computed in the above .

subsection.p: Recall from this that the identity matrix is the n\times n matrix I_n whose columns are the standard coordinate vectors in \R^n. The identity matrix is the standard matrix of the identity transformation: that is, x = \operatorname{Id}_{\R^n}(x) = I_nx for all vectors x in \R^n. For any linear transformation T : \R^n \to \R^m we have I_{\R^m} \circ T = T and by the same token we have for any m \times n matrix A we have I_mA=A. Similarly, we have T \circ I_{\R^n} = T and AI_n=A.

subsection.title: The algebra of transformations and matrices
subsection.p: In this subsection we describe two more operations that one can perform on transformations: addition and scalar multiplication. We then translate these operations into the language of matrices. This is analogous to what we did for the composition of linear transformations, but much less subtle.

ul.li: Let T,U\colon\R^n\to\R^m be two transformations. Their sum is the transformation T+U\colon\R^n\to\R^m defined by (T+U)(x) = T(x) + U(x). Note that addition of transformations is only defined when both transformations have the same domain and codomain.
Let T\colon\R^n\to\R^m be a transformation, and let c be a scalar. The scalar product of c with T is the transformation cT\colon\R^n\to\R^m defined by (cT)(x) = c\cdot T(x).

subsection.p: To emphasize, the sum of two transformations T,U\colon\R^n\to\R^m is another transformation called T+U; its value on an input vector x is the sum of the outputs of T and U. Similarly, the product of T with a scalar c is another transformation called cT; its value on an input vector x is the vector c\cdot T(x).

example.title: Functions of one variable
example.p: Define f\colon\R\to\R by f(x) = x^2 and g\colon\R\to\R by g(x) = x^3. The sum f+g\colon\R\to\R is the transformation defined by the rule (f+g)(x) = f(x) + g(x) = x^2 + x^3. For instance, (f+g)(-2) = (-2)^2 + (-2)^3 = -4.
Define \exp\colon\R\to\R by \exp(x) = e^x. The product 2\exp\colon\R\to\R is the transformation defined by the rule (2\exp)(x) = 2\cdot\exp(x) = 2e^x. For instance, (2\exp)(1) = 2\cdot\exp(1) = 2e.

note.title: Properties of addition and scalar multiplication for transformations
note.p:
Let S,T,U\colon\R^n\to\R^m be transformations and let c,d be scalars. The following properties are easily verified:
T + U \amp= U + T \amp S + (T + U) \amp= (S + T) + U
c(T + U) \amp= cT + cU \amp (c + d)T \amp= cT + dT
c(dT) \amp= (cd)T \amp T + 0 \amp= T

subsection.p: 0The zero transformation In one of the above properties, we used 0 to denote the transformation \R^n\to\R^m that is zero on every input vector: 0(x) = 0 for all x. This is called the zero transformation.
We now give the analogous operations for matrices.

fact.p:
Let T,U\colon\R^n\to\R^m be linear transformations with standard matrices A,B, respectively, and let c be a scalar.
The standard matrix for T+U is A+B.
The standard matrix for cT is cA.

subsection.p: In view of the above fact, the following properties are consequences of the corresponding properties of transformations. They are easily verified directly from the definitions as well.

note.title: Properties of addition and scalar multiplication for matrices
note.p:
Let A,B,C be m\times n matrices and let c,d be scalars. Then:
A + B \amp= B + A \amp C + (A + B) \amp= (C + A) + B
c(A + B) \amp= cA + cB \amp (c + d)A \amp= cA + dA
c(dA) \amp= (cd)A \amp A + 0 \amp= A

subsection.p: 0The zero matrix In one of the above properties, we used 0 to denote the m\times n matrix whose entries are all zero. This is the standard matrix of the zero transformation, and is called the zero matrix.

We can also combine addition and scalar multiplication of matrices with multiplication of matrices. Since matrix multiplication corresponds to composition of transformations (), the following properties are consequences of the corresponding properties of transformations.

note.title: Properties of matrix multiplication
note.p:
Let A,B,C be matrices and let c be a scalar. Suppose that A is an m\times n matrix, and that in each of the following identities, the sizes of B and C are compatible when necessary for the product to be defined. Then:
C(A+B) \amp= C A+C B \amp (A + B) C \amp= A C + B C \amp
c(A B) \amp= (cA) B \amp c(A B) \amp= A(cB)
A I_n \amp= A \amp I_m A \amp= A
(A B)C \amp= A (BC) \amp

subsection.p: Most of the above properties are easily verified directly from the definitions. The associativity property (AB)C=A(BC), however, is not (try it!). It is much easier to prove by relating matrix multiplication to composition of transformations, and using the obvious fact that composition of transformations is associative.
